revision.text: {{EngvarB|date=April 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=April 2016}} The '''2009 Southeast Asian haze''' was an episode of large scale [[air pollution]] primarily caused by [[slash and burn]] practices used to clear land for agricultural purposes in [[Sumatra]], [[Indonesia]]. It affected the areas surrounding the [[Straits of Malacca]] which besides Indonesia include [[Malaysia]] and [[Singapore]]. The haze began in early June 2009 and progressively became worse toward July. With a prevailing dry season caused by [[El Nino]], burning and hence the haze was expected to continue until August or September when the [[monsoon]] season arrived.{{cite news | title=Indonesia forest fires flare, Malaysia hit by haze | publisher=Reuters | date=12 June 2009 | url=http://in.reuters.com/article/environmentNews/idINTRE55B1BX20090612?sp=true}} ==Malaysia== ===Air Pollution revision.text:
{{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Acquired generalized lipodystrophy | image = | alt = | caption = | pronounce = | synonyms = Lawrence-Seip syndrome | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }} '''Acquired generalized lipodystrophy''' (also known as "Lawrence syndrome,"<ref name="Bolognia">{{cite book|title=Dermatology: 2-Volume Set|author1=Rapini, Ronald P.|author2=Bolognia, Jean L.|author3=Jorizzo, Joseph L.|publisher=Mosby|year=2007|isbn=978-1-4160-2999-1|location=St. Louis|pages=|doi=|oclc=|accessdate=}}</ref> and "Lawrence–Seip syndrome",<ref name="Bolognia" /> abbreviation: AGL) is a rare [[skin condition]] that appears during childhood or adolescence, characterized by [[Lipodystrophy|fat loss]] affecting large areas of the body, particularly the face, arms, and legs.<ref name="Andrews">{{cite book|title=Andrews' Diseases of the Skin: clinical Dermatology|author1=James, William D.|author2=Berger, Timothy G.|publisher=Saunders Elsevier|year=2006|isbn=978-0-7216-2921-6|location=|pages=|doi=|oclc=|display-authors=etal|accessdate=}}</ref>{{rp|496}} There are 4 types of [[lipodystrophy]] based on its onset and areas affected: acquired or [[Inherited disease|inherited]] ([[Congenital disorder|congenital]] or familial), and generalized or [[Partial lipodystrophy|partial]]. Both acquired or inherited lipodystrophy present as loss of [[adipose tissue]]s. The near-total loss of [[subcutaneous tissue|subcutaneous]] [[adipose tissue]] is termed generalized lipodystrophy while the selective loss of adipose tissues is denoted as partial lipodystrophy.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=Rebecca J.|last2=Chan|first2=Jean L.|last3=Jaffe|first3=Elaine S.|last4=Cochran|first4=Elaine|last5=DePaoli|first5=Alex M.|last6=Gautier|first6=Jean-Francois|last7=Goujard|first7=Cecile|last8=Vigouroux|first8=Corinne|last9=Gorden|first9=Phillip|date=2016-01-02|title=Lymphoma in acquired generalized lipodystrophy|journal=Leukemia & Lymphoma|volume=57|issue=1|pages=45–50|doi=10.3109/10428194.2015.1040015|pmid=25864863|pmc=4755279}}</ref> Thus, as the name suggests, AGL is a near-total deficiency of adipose tissues in the body that is developed later in life. It is an extremely rare disease that only about 100 cases are reported worldwide.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Garg|first=Abhimanyu|date=2004-03-18|title=Acquired and Inherited Lipodystrophies|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=350|issue=12|pages=1220–1234|doi=10.1056/nejmra025261|pmid=15028826}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.orpha.net/consor/cgi-bin/OC_Exp.php?lng=EN&Expert=79086|title=Orphanet: Acquired generalized lipodystrophy|last=RESERVED|first=INSERM US14 -- ALL RIGHTS|website=www.orpha.net|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> There are three main etiologies of AGL suspected: [[Autoimmunity|autoimmune]], [[panniculitis]]-associated, or [[Idiopathy|idiopathic]].<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Hussain|first=Iram|last2=Garg|first2=Abhimanyu|title=Lipodystrophy Syndromes|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0889852916300706|journal=Endocrinology and Metabolism Clinics of North America|volume=45|issue=4|pages=783–797|doi=10.1016/j.ecl.2016.06.012|pmid=27823605|pmc=4947059|year=2016}}</ref> After its onset, the disease progresses over a few days, weeks, months, or even in years.<ref name=":2" /> Clinical presentations of AGL are similar to other lipodystrophies, including metabolic complications and hypoleptinemia.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":1" /> Treatments are also similar and mainly supportive for symptomatic alleviation. Although HIV- or drug-induced lipodystrophy are a type of acquired lipodystrophy, its origin is very specific and distinct hence is usually not discussed with AGL (see [[HIV-associated lipodystrophy|HIV-Associated Lipodystrophy]]).
== Symptoms == The clinical presentation is similar to people with [[congenital lipodystrophy]]: the only difference is that AGL patients are born with normal fat distribution and symptoms develop in childhood and adolescence years and rarely begins after 30 years of age.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":9" /> Females are more often affected than males, with ratio being 3:1.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite book|title=Greenspan's basic & clinical endocrinology|others=Gardner, David G.,, Shoback, Dolores M.,, Greenspan, Francis S. (Francis Sorrel), 1920-|isbn=9781259589287|edition=Tenth|location=[New York]|oclc=995848612|last1 = Gardner|first1 = David G.|last2=Shoback|first2=Dolores M.|date=2017-10-10}}</ref>
The hallmark characteristics are widespread loss of [[Subcutaneous tissue|subcutaneous fat]], ectopic fat deposition, [[leptin]] deficiency, and severe [[Metabolic syndrome|metabolic abnormalities]] such as [[insulin resistance]].<ref name=":8">{{Cite journal|last=Musso|first=Carla|last2=Major|first2=Maria Laura|last3=Andres|first3=Eugenia|last4=Simha|first4=Vinaya|date=2017-01-05|title=Metreleptin Treatment in Three Patients with Generalized Lipodystrophy|journal=Clinical Medicine Insights: Case Reports|language=en|volume=9|pages=123–127|doi=10.4137/ccrep.s40196|pmid=28096701|pmc=5217977}}</ref> Subcutaneous fat loss in AGL patients are visible in all parts of the body. AGL mostly affects face and the extremities and may look sunken or swollen in the eyes.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5" /> However, the degree and location of severity may vary by person.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5" /> Especially, intra-abdominal fat loss is variable.<ref name=":9" /> As subcutaneous fat is lost, affected areas show prominent structures of veins and muscle. Those with panniculitis-associated AGL may present erythematous nodules.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Billings|first=J. K.|last2=Milgraum|first2=S. S.|last3=Gupta|first3=A. K.|last4=Headington|first4=J. T.|last5=Rasmussen|first5=J. E.|date=December 1987|title=Lipoatrophic panniculitis: a possible autoimmune inflammatory disease of fat. Report of three cases|journal=Archives of Dermatology|volume=123|issue=12|pages=1662–1666|pmid=3688906|doi=10.1001/archderm.123.12.1662}}</ref>
Metabolic complications include insulin resistance, high metabolic rate, and uncontrolled lipid levels such as hypertriglyceridemia, low HDL, and high LDL. Patients may develop [[diabetes mellitus]] secondary to [[insulin resistance]].
Recent case reports revealed that [[lymphoma]] is present in some patients but its prevalence is not known at this time.<ref name=":7" />
== Cause == There is no known cause for this disease; however, three origins of AGL are generally suspected: [[panniculitis]]-associated, [[Autoimmunity|autoimmune]]-associated, and [[Idiopathy|idiopathic]] AGLs.<ref name=":1" /> Triggers may include [[infection]]s that aggravate the [[panniculitis]], or any disease state that can induce [[autoimmunity]]. Overlap between panniculitis and autoimmune types also exists.<ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=Handelsman|first=Yehuda|last2=Oral|first2=Elif A.|last3=Bloomgarden|first3=Zachary T.|last4=Brown|first4=Rebecca J.|last5=Chan|first5=Jean L.|last6=Einhorn|first6=Daniel|last7=Garber|first7=Alan J.|last8=Garg|first8=Abhimanyu|last9=Garvey|first9=W. Timothy|date=2013|title=THE CLINICAL APPROACH TO THE DETECTION OF LIPODYSTROPHY – AN AACE CONSENSUS STATEMENT|journal=Endocrine Practice : Official Journal of the American College of Endocrinology and the American Association of Clinical Endocrinologists|volume=19|issue=1|pages=107–116|pmc=4108221|pmid=23435042|doi=10.4158/endp.19.1.v767575m65p5mr06}}</ref> Another theory suggest that AGL is an autoimmune disease itself, as panniculitis can be described as an autoimmune disease, however its triggering factors remains to be unknown.<ref name=":9" /> Underlying [[Genetics|genetic]] factor may be associated; however neither confirmed nor rejected.<ref name=":1" />
=== [[Panniculitis]]-associated AGL ===
About 25% of previously reported AGL is associated with [[panniculitis]].<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> [[Panniculitis]] is an inflammatory nodules of the subcutaneous fat, and in this type of AGL, adipose destruction originates locally at the infection or inflammation site and develops into [[Lipodystrophy|generalized lipodystrophy]].<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":9" />
=== [[Autoimmunity|Autoimmune]]-associated AGL ===
AGL with autoimmune origin is responsible for about 25% of all AGL reports.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /> Those with autoimmune origin stems from other autoimmune diseases, most commonly with [[juvenile dermatomyositis]] and [[autoimmune hepatitis]], but also occurs with [[rheumatoid arthritis]], [[Systemic lupus erythematosus|systemic lupus erythematous]], and [[Sjögren syndrome|Sjogren syndrome]].<ref name=":3" />
=== [[Idiopathy|Idiopathic]] AGL ===
Although idiopathic AGL accounts for about 50% of all AGL, it can vary in its origin and its is unclear how it develops.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3" /><ref name=":4" />
No known preventive measurement has been reported.
== Mechanism == The exact pathophysiologic mechanism is mostly unknown; however, each of three main origins, autoimmune, panniculitis, or idiopathic, may have different mechanisms of pathogenesis.<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Nolis|first=Tom|title=Exploring the pathophysiology behind the more common genetic and acquired lipodystrophies|journal=Journal of Human Genetics|volume=59|issue=1|pages=16–23|doi=10.1038/jhg.2013.107|pmid=24152769|year=2013}}</ref>
Normally, [[adipose tissue]]s contain [[adipocyte]]s to store fat for energy during [[fasting]] period and release [[leptin]] to regulate [[homeostasis]] of energy and sensitize insulin. In AGL patients, adipose tissues are insufficient and leads to fat deposition in non-adipose tissues, such as [[muscle]] or [[liver]], resulting in [[hypertriglyceridemia]]. Continuous elevation in [[triglyceride]] levels further contributes to metabolic problems including [[insulin resistance]].<ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Oral|first=Elif Arioglu|last2=Simha|first2=Vinaya|last3=Ruiz|first3=Elaine|last4=Andewelt|first4=Alexa|last5=Premkumar|first5=Ahalya|last6=Snell|first6=Peter|last7=Wagner|first7=Anthony J.|last8=DePaoli|first8=Alex M.|last9=Reitman|first9=Marc L.|date=2002-02-21|title=Leptin-Replacement Therapy for Lipodystrophy|journal=New England Journal of Medicine|volume=346|issue=8|pages=570–578|doi=10.1056/nejmoa012437|pmid=11856796}}</ref> As the level of [[leptin]] in the body is proportional to the amount of adipose tissue present, AGL patients also have a deficiency of [[leptin]] which contributes to excessive eating and worsens the [[metabolic syndrome]].<ref name=":4" />
In a few patients with AGL, the presence of [[Antibody|antibodies]] against [[adipocyte]] has been identified.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Hübler|first=A.|last2=Abendroth|first2=K.|last3=Keiner|first3=T.|last4=Stöcker|first4=W.|last5=Kauf|first5=E.|last6=Hein|first6=G.|last7=Stein|first7=G.|date=1998|title=Dysregulation of insulin-like growth factors in a case of generalized acquired lipoatrophic diabetes mellitus (Lawrence Syndrome) connected with autoantibodies against adipocyte membranes|journal=Experimental and Clinical Endocrinology & Diabetes|volume=106|issue=1|pages=79–84|doi=10.1055/s-0029-1211955|pmid=9516065}}</ref>
== Diagnosis == Diagnosis is made comprehensively, together with visual observation, body fat assessment, a review of lab panels consisting of A1c, glucose, lipid, and patient history.
Caliper measurements of skinfold thickness is recommended to quantify fat loss as a supportive information.<ref name=":9" /> In this measurement, skinfold thickness of less than 10mm for men and 22mm for women at the anterior thigh is suggestive cutoff for the diagnosis of lipodystrophy.<ref name=":9" /> Less commonly, biphotonic absorptiometry and [[magnetic resonance imaging]] (MRI) can be done for the measurement of body fat.<ref name=":1" />
Other forms of insulin resistance may be assessed for [[differential diagnosis]].<ref name=":1" /> Resistance to conventional therapy for hyperglycemia and hypertriglyceridemia serves as an indication for lipodystrophy. Specifically, the diagnosis is strongly considered for those requiring ≥200 units/day of insulin and persistent elevation of ≥250 mg/dl of triglyceride levels.<ref name=":9" />
The use of leptin levels should be carefully approached.<ref name=":9" /> While low leptin levels are helpful for making the diagnosis, they are not specific for the lipodystrophy. High leptin levels can help excluding the possible lipodystrophy, but there is no well-established standardized leptin ranges.
== Treatment and prognosis == Initial and general approach for AGL patients are to treat the metabolic complications such as [[leptin]]-replacement therapy and/or to control the abnormal levels of [[lipid]]s or [[glucose]] levels.<ref name=":4" /> [[Anti-diabetic medication]]s such as [[insulin]], [[metformin]], or [[thiazolidinedione]]s are used for insulin-resistance or high glucose levels, or [[statin]]s or [[fibrate]]s are used for [[hyperlipidemia]]. If symptoms persist, [[metreleptin]] can be prescribed.
[[Metreleptin]] (MYALEPT'''<sup>®</sup>)''' is a recombinant human [[leptin]] analog and was approved by FDA in 2014 for generalized lipodystrophy as an adjunct therapy to diet to treat the complication of [[leptin]] deficiency.<ref name=":6">{{Cite web|url=http://www.myalept.com/|title=Homepage {{!}} Myalept|website=www.myalept.com|language=en|access-date=2017-11-07}}</ref> It is the only drug option approved for generalized lipodystrophy-related symptoms and is not intended to use for patients with [[HIV-associated lipodystrophy|HIV-related lipodystrophy]] or complications of [[partial lipodystrophy]].<ref name=":6" /> Although it is a recombinant human leptin analog, it is not completely the same as natural leptin as it is produced in ''[[Escherichia coli|e. coli]]'' and has added [[methionine]] residues at is amino terminus.<ref name=":6" /> It works by binding to the human [[leptin receptor]], [[Leptin receptor|ObR]], and activates the [[Receptor (biochemistry)|receptor]].<ref name=":6" /> The receptor belongs to the Class I [[Cytokine|cytokine family]] and signals the [[JAK-STAT signaling pathway|JAK/STAT pathway]]. It is available as 11.3 mg powder in a vial for subcutaneous injection upon reconstitution and needs to be protected from the light. For treatment, patients and their doctors need to be enrolled and certified in the [[Metreleptin|Myalept]]'''<sup>®</sup>''' [[Risk evaluation and mitigation strategy|Risk Evaluation and Mitigation Strategy (REMS)]] Program because people on this treatment has a risk of developing anti-metreleptin [[Antibody|antibodies]] that decrease the effectiveness of metreleptin, and increased risk of [[lymphoma]].<ref name=":6" /> Clinical study with GL patients who took [[metreleptin]] had increased [[insulin]] sensitivity, as indicated by decreased [[Glycated hemoglobin|HbA1c]] and fasting glucose level, and reduced caloric intake as well as fasting [[triglyceride]] levels.<ref name=":4" />
[[Plasmapheresis]] was previously an option for lowering extremely high [[triglyceride]] levels for preventing [[pancreatitis]] and painful [[xanthoma]], but its use has been decreased after the approval of metreleptin.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bolan|first=Charles|last2=Oral|first2=Elif Arioglu|last3=Gorden|first3=Phillip|last4=Taylor|first4=Simeon|last5=Leitman|first5=Susan F.|date=January 2002|title=Intensive, long-term plasma exchange therapy for severe hypertriglyceridemia in acquired generalized lipoatrophy|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology and Metabolism|volume=87|issue=1|pages=380–384|doi=10.1210/jcem.87.1.8176|pmid=11788680}}</ref>
Cosmetic treatments, such as [[facial reconstruction]] or [[Implant (body modification)|implant]]<nowiki/>s, can be done <nowiki/>to replace [[adipose tissue]]s.
Lifestyle modifications are also recommended, including changes into less fat diet and exercise.
The [[prognosis]] of the disease is unknown as of December, 2017.<ref name=":1" />
== Recent research == Many researches for the treatment of lipodystrophy focus on the safety and efficacy of leptin replacement therapy and the outlook is positive in many studies.
According to a prospective, open-label clinical study at the NIH, metreleptin decreased the fasting glucose level from 180 mg/dL to 121 mg/dL, HbA1c from 8.4% to 6.4%, total cholesterol from 214 mg/dL to 146 mg/dL, and triglycerides from 467 (200-847)mg/dL to 180 (106-312)mg/dL after 12 months of use (p<0.001).<ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=Diker-Cohen|first=Talia|last2=Cochran|first2=Elaine|last3=Gorden|first3=Phillip|last4=Brown|first4=Rebecca J.|date=2015-05-01|title=Partial and Generalized Lipodystrophy: Comparison of Baseline Characteristics and Response to Metreleptin|journal=The Journal of Clinical Endocrinology & Metabolism|volume=100|issue=5|pages=1802–1810|doi=10.1210/jc.2014-4491|pmid=25734254|pmc=4422900}}</ref> Patients also had decreased use of anti-diabetic medications, lipid-lowering medications, and insulin (p<0.001).<ref name=":10" /> In other clinical reports studying 3 patients diagnosed with AGL accompanied by hypoleptinemia, uncontrolled diabetes, and hypertriglyceridemia who were treated with metreleptin for 12–168 weeks, patients had great reduction in HbA1c, from 10.9% to 5.8%, and had normalized serum triglycerides with a mean decline of 90%. Patients reported improved quality of life and reduced need for other medications without significant adverse effects.<ref name=":8" />
One research published in 2017 reported an middle-aged patient developed AGL after treatment and recovery for autoimmune thrombocytopenia that included immunoglobulin therapy and prednisone,<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Cunningham|first=Julia|last2=Nadal|first2=Rosa|last3=Broome|first3=Catherine|title=Acquired Generalized Lipodystrophy Following Immune Thrombocytopenia|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S000293431730503X|journal=The American Journal of Medicine|volume=130|issue=10|pages=e445–e446|doi=10.1016/j.amjmed.2017.04.035|pmid=28549922|year=2017}}</ref> which suggests the autoimmune trigger may contribute to the development of AGL.
Other researches focus on genetics of lipodystrophy; however its relevance to acquired generalized lipodystrophy has not been confirmed so far. One clinical report published in July 2017 stated two brothers with juvenile-onset generalized lipodystrophy was due to [[lamin]] C-specific mutation but it is unknown at this point if this will fall into acquired or familial lipodystrophy.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Patni|first=Nivedita|last2=Xing|first2=Chao|last3=Agarwal|first3=Anil K.|last4=Garg|first4=Abhimanyu|date=2017-09-01|title=Juvenile-onset generalized lipodystrophy due to a novel heterozygous missense LMNA mutation affecting lamin C|journal=American Journal of Medical Genetics Part A|language=en|volume=173|issue=9|pages=2517–2521|doi=10.1002/ajmg.a.38341|pmid=28686329|pmc=5593256}}</ref>
There has been many published case reports. Meta-analysis of published case reports published within the decade will be very helpful in establishing patient demographic, etiologies, and prognosis of the diagnosis.
== See also == * [[Lipodystrophy]] * [[List of cutaneous conditions]] * [[HIV-associated lipodystrophy]]

{{notability|Companies|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox company| | name = American Council on Exercise | logo = [[File:Acefitnesslogo.jpg|logo|American Council on Exercise Logo]] | type = [[Non-profit company|Non-profit]] | foundation = {{start date and age|1985}} | location_city = [[San Diego]], [[California]] | location_country = [[United States|U.S.]] | key_people = [[Scott Goudeseune (CEO), Alex Mirnezam (CFO)]] | num_employees = 98 | homepage = [http://www.acefitness.org www.acefitness.org] | footnotes = }} The '''American Council on Exercise''' ('''ACE''') is a [[nonprofit]] fitness certification, education and training provider with more than 73,000<ref>{{cite web|title=Ace Personal Training Certification|url=http://www.healthcureplus.com/personal-training-certification/|website=Healthcureplus.com}}</ref> certified professionals who hold more than 83,000 ACE certifications. Founded in 1985, American Council on Exercise (ACE)'s national headquarters is located in [[San Diego]].
==Certifications== In 2003, American Council on Exercise was granted accreditation by the [[National Commission for Certifying Agencies]] for all four of its primary certification programs.<ref>http://www.acefitness.org/aboutace/accreditation.aspx</ref>
==Leadership==
Scott Goudeseune is president and chief executive officer.<ref>http://www.acefitness.org/aboutace/executiveteam.aspx</ref>
==See also== *[[Personal Trainer]] * [[Board of Certification, Inc.]]
== References ==
<references />4. http://destination-jacked.com
== External links == * [http://www.ideafit.com/organization/ace ACE Profile] * [http://www.acefitness.org/ American Council on Exercise] * [http://www.starting-a-personal-training-business.com/acsm-personal-trainer-certification.html ACSM Certification Requirements]

revision.text:
The '''British Occupational Hygiene Society''' (BOHS), whose vision is ''a healthy working environment for everyone'', was established as a charity in 1953 to reduce work-related ill-health, and makes a distinct and valuable contribution to preventing ill-health in the workplace. BOHS is both a learned society, publishing the world-renowned, scientific, peer-reviewed journal, ''Annals of Occupational Hygiene'',<ref>[http://annhyg.oxfordjournals.org/ Annals of Occupational Hygiene]</ref> and the only professional society representing qualified [[occupational hygienists]] in the UK. The Society supports, develops and connects its members with resources, guidance, events and training, and encourages new members. Its Faculty of Occupational Hygiene sets professional standards and is the only UK examining board for qualifications in occupational hygiene which are recognised internationally.
BOHS is the only UK based organisation that: * brings together everyone involved in the science and practical application of occupational hygiene * champions and facilitates the development of professional competency * promotes the science and practice of occupational hygiene worldwide
== Occupational hygiene == Occupational hygiene is the scientific discipline that protects people against the wide range of health risks that can arise from exposure to health hazards at work. The breadth of knowledge and skills brought together in occupational hygiene is unique.
It focuses: * on the recognition of hazards, assessment of exposure, and control of risks to health * at the interface of people with the workplace and work activities * where science and engineering meet the human element of work
== Structure == BOHS is a not-for-profit, non-governmental organisation which is managed by a board of directors, known as the Council. The Faculty of Occupational Hygiene is run by the Faculty Board and reports to Council through its Registrar. The Society’s Head Office, based in Derby, is led by a Chief Executive who is directly accountable to Council, with a senior management team responsible for finance and operations, membership services, conferences and events, publications, examinations management, marketing and communications, and overall administrative services. It also has a range of committees, chaired by members and with input from other volunteers and staff; these committees, alongside a team of regional organisers (also volunteers from the membership) provide technical, strategic and project-by-project input to the Society’s various initiatives and on-going activities.
== Faculty of Occupational Hygiene == The Faculty of Occupational Hygiene is the professional arm of BOHS. Membership is restricted to BOHS members with specific qualifications in occupational hygiene and related subjects.
As the examining board for the profession, the Faculty administers a suite of examinations and awards qualifications in occupational hygiene and allied subjects, and provides a qualifications’ verification service.
The Faculty also runs the Continuing Professional Development (CPD) Scheme, which is mandatory for all non-retired Faculty members.
It maintains a Directory of Occupational Hygiene Services,<ref>[http://www.bohs.org/OHServices-directory/ Directory of Occupational Hygiene Services] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110614161913/http://www.bohs.org/OHServices-directory/ |date=June 14, 2011 }} British Occupational Hygiene Society</ref> which is searchable online or available in hard copy, and is free of charge.
==Affiliations== BOHS is a founding member of the International Occupational Hygiene Association (IOHA). It has collaborated with other global organisations including the [[International Labour Organization]], [[World Health Organization]], [[American Industrial Hygiene Association]], [[National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health]], [[Institute of Occupational Medicine]], [[Institution of Occupational Safety and Health]], and [[Institute of Ergonomics and Human Factors]], among others to carry out research, develop training and sponsor conferences.<ref>[http://www.bohs.org/usefullinkspartners/ Partner Organisations] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111001134123/http://www.bohs.org/usefullinkspartners/ |date=October 1, 2011 }}. British Occupational Hygiene Society.</ref>
The British Occupational Hygiene Society has worked in partnership with a number of health and safety professional bodies to develop the Occupational Safety & Health Consultant Register ([[OSHCR]]). This will establish a new benchmark standard for health and safety consultants and help to raise the quality of advice being given to businesses.<ref>[http://www.oshcr.org/ Occupational Safety & Health Consultants Register]. OSHCR.</ref>
==Publications== BOHS publishes the ''Annals of Occupational Hygiene'', a peer-reviewed scientific journal (via [[Oxford University Press]]). Additionally, the Society produces Exposure magazine, e-bulletins, guidance and position statements, and a directory of occupational hygiene services.<ref>[http://www.bohs.org/library/ Publications] British Occupational Hygiene Society.</ref>
==Awards== Every two years, BOHS awards the Thomas Bedford Memorial Prize. Named for the society's first president and instituted initially in 1978, the prize is given to the best paper in the ''Annals of Occupational Hygiene'' and includes a £500 award. BOHS also gives the Ted King and David Hickish Awards to recognize top certificate- and diploma-earning hygienists. Annually, the Peter Isaac Award is given each year to honor an occupational hygienist for valuable contributions workplace health. The Bedford Award which was instituted in 1978, named after the first President of BOHS, Thomas Bedford CBE, and is the Society’s prime honour. It is awarded irregularly, and marks outstanding contributions to the discipline of occupational hygiene, either in the general field or in work for the Society. <ref>[http://www.bohs.org/aboutus/awards/ BOHS Awards]. British Occupational Hygiene Society.</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.bohs.org/ British Occupational Hygiene Society] *[http://annhyg.oxfordjournals.org/ ''Annals of Occupational Hygiene''] *[http://www.ioha.net/ International Occupational Hygiene Association] *[http://www.who.int/en/ World Health Organization] *[http://www.aiha.org/ American Industrial Hygiene Association] *[https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/ National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health] *[http://www.IOM-world.org/ Institute of Occupational Medicine] *[http://www.hsl.gov.uk/ Health and Safety Laboratory] *[http://www.iosh.co.uk/ Institution of Occupational Safety and Health] *[https://web.archive.org/web/19961227182911/http://www.ergonomics.org.uk/ Institute of Ergonomics and Human Factors] *[http://www.OH-world.org/ OH-world.org, a website for people interested in occupational hygiene]

{{Medref|date=June 2016}} '''Candex''' is a [[dietary supplement]] manufactured by [[Pure Essence Laboratories]]. It is marketed as an [[enzyme|enzymatic]] remedy to treat the yeast infection [[Candida (genus)|candida]]. Having the status of a [[dietary supplement]], its efficiency has not been proven in scientifically controlled and peer-reviewed trials. Similar formulas exist, such as [[Candigest]].
==Mechanism of action== Candex contains the fibre digesting [[enzyme]]s, [[cellulase]] and hemicellulase. The manufacturer claims because yeast cell walls are built mainly of fibre, which is mostly made of the complex carbohydrate, [[cellulose]], cellulase and hemicellulase are capable of killing yeast.
However, a review of the scientific literature suggests that this mechanism of action is unlikely to be true. For while plant [[cell wall]]s are made predominantly of [[cellulose]], yeast [[cell wall]]s are not ([[yeast]] are classified as fungi). For example, in the article, "Synthesis of the yeast cell wall and its regulation" in the ''Annual Review of Biochemistry'', there is mention of many other complex carbohydrates found in yeast cell walls, but there is no mention of cellulose<ref name="Synthesis of the Yeast Cell Wall and its Regulation">{{cite journal | url=http://www.annualreviews.org/doi/abs/10.1146/annurev.bi.51.070182.003555 | title=Synthesis of the Yeast Cell Wall and its Regulation | author=E Cabib | author2=R Roberts | author3=B Bowers | last-author-amp=yes | journal=Annual Review of Biochemistry |date=July 1982 | volume=51 | pages=763–793 | doi=10.1146/annurev.bi.51.070182.003555}}</ref> nor is cellulose mentioned as a cell wall component in ''[[candida albicans]]'', the yeast strain most frequently associated with human fungal infections.<ref name="Surface Glycans of Candida albicans">{{cite journal | title=Surface Glycans of Candida albicans and Other Pathogenic Fungi | author=Masuoka, J | journal=Clinical Reviews of Microbiology |date=April 2004 | volume=17 | issue=2 | pages=281–310 | doi=10.1128/cmr.17.2.281-310.2004 | pmid=15084502 | pmc=387410}}</ref> Indeed, scientists have even modified yeast cells so they can make their own cellulases. This allows the modified yeast to ferment widely available plant material, which is made mostly of cellulose, and turn plant cellulose into alcohol for biofuels ([[cellulosic ethanol]]). One scientific article even called yeast an "ideal host strain" for producing cellulases.<ref name="Endowing non-cellulolytic microorganisms with cellulolytic activity">{{cite journal | pmid=23473971 | title=Endowing non-cellulolytic microorganisms with cellulolytic activity aiming for consolidated bioprocessing. | vauthors=Yamada R, Hasunuma T, Kondo A | journal=Biotechnol Adv |date=Nov 2013 | volume=31 | issue=6 | pages=754–63 | doi=10.1016/j.biotechadv.2013.02.007}}</ref> This is consistent with cellulase not being toxic to yeast and no mention was made of any toxic effect of cellulases on the modified yeast.
Furthermore, while many internet sites claim that cellulase enzymes might degrade the [[chitin]] found in yeast cell walls, once again no evidence is presented for this. [[Enzymes]] are known to be highly specific and in general cellulases have not been found to be active on chitin. To quote one scientific article: "The purified cellulase was devoid of chitinase, pectinase and mannanase activities".<ref name="Substrate Specificity of a Cellulase">{{cite journal | url=http://www.biochemj.org/bj/169/0389/1690389.pdf | title=Substrate Specificity and Mode ofAction of a Celiulase | author=PL Hurst | author2=PA Sullivan | author3=MG Sheperd | journal=Biochem. J. | year=1978 | volume=169 | pages=390}}</ref> Moreover, in contrast to the previously mentioned fact that yeast bioengineered to make cellulases remain healthy,<ref name="Endowing non-cellulolytic microorganisms with cellulolytic activity" /> when a [[chitinase]] gene was bioengineered into the same yeast strain it resulted in complete growth inhibition.<ref name="Growth inhibition">{{cite journal | title=Growth inhibition of the yeast transformant by the expression of a chitinase from Coprinellus congregatus. | vauthors=Lim H, Choi HT | journal=J Microbiol |date=Oct 2010 | volume=48 | issue=5 | pages=706–708 | doi=10.1007/s12275-010-0272-x | pmid=21046352}}</ref> This again suggests cellulases do not in general contain significant chitinase activity.
Similarly, although many internet sites claim cellulase degrades yeast [[biofilm]]s, no peer-reviewed scientific evidence was offered in support of this. The exact chemical composition of yeast biofilms remains poorly understood and although there is evidence for it containing many different types of [[polysaccharides]], there was no evidence presented that it contains [[cellulose]] or is susceptible to cellulase digest.<ref name="Biofilm matrix of Candida albicans">{{cite journal | url=http://jmm.sgmjournals.org/content/55/8/999.long | title=Biofilm matrix of Candida albicans and Candida tropicalis: chemical composition and role in drug resistance | author=MA Al-Fattani | author2=LJ Douglas | last-author-amp=yes | journal=Journal of Medical Microbiology |date=Aug 2006 | volume=55 | pages=999–1008 | doi=10.1099/jmm.0.46569-0 | issue=8}}</ref>
The manufacturer further claims Candex enzymes kill yeast but don't stimulate the yeast to release toxins, thereby avoiding unpleasant [[Herxheimer reaction|die-off]] reactions, contrary to using [[fungicide|fungicidal]] drugs and herbs. But once again, there is no reference to a [[peer-reviewed]] scientific journal to support these claims. An alternative explanation might be that there are no unpleasant die-off reactions simply because the Candex enzymes do not effectively kill yeast.
The remaining enzymes found in Candex: [[amylase]], [[glucoamylase]], [[diastase]], and [[invertase]] are involved in basic carbohydrate and sugar [[metabolic]] pathways and are not involved in cell wall [[lysis]]. For example, [[Invertase]] catalyzes the conversion of [[sucrose]] (common table sugar) into [[glucose]] and [[fructose]]. Much of the invertase used in the food industry is actually purified from yeast itself as yeast contain an abundance of their own naturally produced invertase.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.eng.umd.edu/~nsw/ench485/lab14.htm | title=Enzyme Kinetics of Invertase | accessdate=5 December 2013 | author=Nam Sun Wang}}</ref>
Candex is sold in sizes of 40 or 120 capsules. 4 capsules equal one daily dose, which may later be reduced. 4 capsules contain:<ref>[http://www.smartbomb.com/pe902.html Pure Essence Candex 120 Cap., SMARTbomb.com]</ref>
{| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- ! Ingredient !! Dose |- | Vegetarian [[Cellulase]] || 148,000 CU |- | Vegetarian [[Hemicellulase]] || 60,000 HCU |- | Vegetarian [[Amylase]] || 8000 DU |- | Vegetarian [[Glucoamylase]] || 400 mg |- | Vegetarian [[Invertase]] || 1200 SU |- | Vegetarian Malt [[Diastase]] || 400 DP |}
==Drug status== {{refimprove section|date=December 2008}} Being classified as a [[dietary supplement]], it is not approved by the US [[Food and Drug Administration]] to diagnose, treat, or prevent any condition of disease.
===Trials and tests=== A non-verified study from 2002 by the Progressive Medical Group claims that after testing the remedy on 52 patients, all of them had "at least minimal improvement not only in any upper gastrointestinal symptoms (probably associated with the natural digestive enzyme), but also in lower gastrointestinal symptoms and yeast-associated problems (altered cognition, craving carbohydrates, arthralgias, myalgias, allergies, etc.)." The study claims that side effects were "minimal with only rare gastrointestinal symptoms (nausea, etc.) that resolved when association with food intake was altered", and that these side effects were deemed to not be statistically significant.<ref>[http://coastherbal.com/product_info.php/products_id/329 Candex, A Clinical Study, CoastHerbal.com]</ref> The study has not been reviewed by scientific peers, nor published in medical journals. Some have questioned its usefulness due to the lack of a control group.
As of January 2007, no [[peer review]]ed articles were indexed by the [[National Library of Medicine]] referencing Candex.<ref>[https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/entrez/query.fcgi?CMD=search&DB=pubmed PubMed database, 21 Jan. 2007]</ref>
==References== <references/>
==External links== *[http://www.pureessencelabs.com/candex.php Candex, Pure Essence Laboratories] *[http://www.pureessencelabs.com/Candex-candida_digestive_enzyme_supplement.html Manufacturer's brochure, Pure Essence Laboratories]
[[Category:Dietary supplements]]

revision.text:
{{Use mdy dates|date=August 2017}} {{redirect|Equal opportunities|the Yes Minister episode|Equal Opportunities (Yes Minister)}} [[File:Sprinter at starting block.jpg|thumb|The [[metaphor]] of a race is often used to describe equality of opportunity|alt=A sprinter at the starting block]] '''Equal opportunity''' (also known as '''equality of opportunity''') arises from the similar treatment of all people, unhampered by artificial barriers or prejudices or preferences, except when particular distinctions can be explicitly justified.<ref name=twsL19/> According to this often complex and contested concept,<ref name=twsL18/> the intent is that important jobs in an organization should go to those persons who are the "most qualified" – persons most likely to perform ably in a given task – and not go to persons for reasons deemed arbitrary or irrelevant, such as circumstances of birth, upbringing, having well-connected [[Nepotism|relatives]] or friends,<ref name=twsH11/> religion, sex,<ref name=twsL25/> ethnicity,<ref name=twsL25>{{citation|author=Yo Jackson (editor)|title=Encyclopedia of multicultural psychology|publisher=Sage Publications|year=2006|isbn=1-4129-0948-1|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_hcurFqnQioC&pg=PA19|accessdate=2011-09-12}}</ref> race, caste,<ref name=twsL13/> or involuntary personal attributes such as [[disability]], age, gender identity, or sexual orientation.<ref name=twsL13/><ref name=twsL16cc>{{citation|title=Equal opportunity|publisher=Princeton University|year=2008|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/equal+opportunity|accessdate=2011-09-12}}</ref> Though accommodation of persons with special needs and disabilities are done through job restructuring activities considering their potential for same level of performance, for experiencing same level of benefits and privileges as others.
Chances for advancement should be open to everybody interested,<ref name=twsL16bb>{{citation|title=equal opportunity|publisher=''Collins English Dictionary''|year=2003|url=http://www.thefreedictionary.com/equal+opportunity|accessdate=2011-09-12}}</ref> such that they have "an equal chance to compete within the framework of goals and the structure of rules established".<ref name=twsH77c>{{citation|author=John W. Gardner|title=Excellence: Can we be equal and excellent too?|publisher=Norton|quote=(see page 47)|year=1984|isbn=0-393-31287-9|url=https://books.google.com/?id=liE59woX624C&pg=PA46&dq=%22equality+of+opportunity%22#v=onepage&q=%22equality%20of%20opportunity%22&f=false|accessdate=2011-09-08}}</ref> The idea is to remove arbitrariness from the selection process and base it on some "pre-agreed basis of [[Social justice|fairness]], with the assessment process being related to the type of position"<ref name=twsH11/> and emphasizing procedural and legal means.<ref name=twsL13/><ref name=twsL23/> Individuals should succeed or fail based on their own efforts and not extraneous circumstances such as having well-connected parents.<ref name=tws2X31>{{citation|author=Valentino Dardanoni, University of Palermo, Gary S. Fields, Cornell University, John E. Roemer, Yale University, Maria Laura Sánchez Puerta, The World Bank|title=How Demanding Should Equality of Opportunity Be, and How Much Have We Achieved?|work=Cornell University – Digital Commons ILR|quote=(from the abstract) [...] Agreement is widespread that equality of opportunity holds in a society if the chances that individuals have to succeed depend only on their own efforts and not on extraneous circumstances.|year=2006|url=http://digitalcommons.ilr.cornell.edu/articles/270/|accessdate=2012-07-24}}</ref> It is opposed to [[nepotism]]<ref name=twsH11/> and plays a role in whether a social structure is seen as legitimate.<ref name=twsH11/><ref name=twsL13/><ref name=twsL15>{{cite news|author=Marjorie Conley|title=Sciences Po – an elite institution's introspection on its power, position and worth in French society|publisher=portfolio|quote=[...] created new entrance criteria for students coming from less economically favored social strata.|date=September 9, 2003|url=http://journalism.nyu.edu/publishing/archives/portfolio/conley/sciencespo.html|accessdate=2011-09-12}}</ref> The concept is applicable in areas of public life in which benefits are earned and received such as [[employment]] and [[education]], although it can apply to many other areas as well. Equal opportunity is central to the concept of [[meritocracy]].
== Differing political viewpoints == [[File:Admiral John Fisher.jpg|thumb|Equal opportunity for all: "We fight God when our Social System dooms the brilliant clever child of a poor man to the same level as his father", [[John Fisher, 1st Baron Fisher|Admiral "Jacky" Fisher]], ''[https://archive.org/stream/cu31924027924509#page/n100/mode/1up Records]'' (1919)]] People with differing political viewpoints often view the concept differently.<ref name=twsH77bxx>{{citation |author= Ricardo Paes de Barros. Francisco H. G. Ferreira, Jose R. Molinas Vega, and Jaime Saavedra Chanduvi |title= Measuring inequality of opportunity in Latin America and the Caribbean |publisher= ''Palgrave Macmillan and the World Bank'' |quote= page xvii |year= 2009 |isbn= 978-0-8213-7745-1 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=ABHXr54-XXUC&pg=PA32&dq=%22equality+of+opportunity%22#v=onepage&q=%22equality%20of%20opportunity%22&f=false |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> The meaning of equal opportunity is debated in fields such as political philosophy, sociology and psychology. It is being applied to increasingly wider areas beyond employment,<ref name=twsL23>{{cite news |title= equal opportunity |publisher= ''jrank.org'' |date= September 12, 2011 |url= http://www.jrank.org/business/pages/508/equal-opportunity.html |accessdate= 2011-09-12 }}</ref><ref name=twsL22/> including lending,<ref>Swire, Peter P.. "Equality of opportunity and investment in creditworthiness. (Symposium – Shaping American Communities: Segregation, Housing & the Urban Poor)." University of Pennsylvania Law Review. University of Pennsylvania, Law School. 1995. [http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1G1-17237458.html Highbeam Research article] September 12, 2012.</ref> housing, college admissions, voting rights and elsewhere.<ref name=twsL19>{{citation |author= Paul de Vries |title= equal opportunity |publisher= ''Blackwell Reference'' |date= September 12, 2011 |url= http://www.blackwellreference.com/public/tocnode?id=g9780631233176_chunk_g97814051001378_ss1-15 |accessdate= 2011-09-12 }}</ref> In the classical sense, equality of opportunity is closely aligned with the concept of [[equality before the law]] and ideas of [[meritocracy]].<ref>{{cite book |title=The Rise of the Meritocracy |last=Young |first=Michael |authorlink= Michael Young (politician) |origyear= 1958 |year=1963 |publisher=Penguin Books |location=Great Britain |isbn=1-56000-704-4 |page=129 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=e_rTyIMJR9kC |accessdate=2011-01-12}}</ref>
Generally, the terms ''equality of opportunity'' and ''equal opportunity'' are interchangeable, with occasional slight variations; the former has more of a sense of being an abstract political concept while "equal opportunity" is sometimes used as an adjective, usually in the context of employment regulations, to identify an employer, a hiring approach, or law. Equal opportunity provisions have been written into regulations and have been debated in courtrooms.<ref name=twsH44>{{cite news |author= Steven Greenhouse |title= E.E.O.C. Sues Kaplan Over Hiring |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |quote= ... the Equal Employment Opportunity Commission sued the Kaplan Higher Education Corporation ... |date= December 21, 2010 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/22/business/22kaplan.html |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> It is sometimes conceived as a [[Rights|legal right]] against [[discrimination]].<ref name=twsL13>{{citation |author1=Nicole Richardt |author2=Torrey Shanks |title= Equal Opportunity |publisher= ''International Encyclopedia of the Social Sciences'' |quote= via Encyclopedia.com |year= 2008 |url= http://www.encyclopedia.com/topic/Equal_Opportunity.aspx |accessdate= 2011-09-12 }}</ref><ref name=twsH73>{{citation |author1=Gerald N. Hill |author2=Kathleen T. Hill |title= equal opportunity |publisher= ''The Free Dictionary'' |date= September 8, 2011 |url= http://legal-dictionary.thefreedictionary.com/Equality+of+opportunity |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref><ref name=twsH75>{{citation |title= equal opportunity |publisher= ''Merriam-Webster'' |url= http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/equal%20opportunity |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> It is an ideal which has become increasingly widespread<ref name=twsL21>{{citation |author= Mark Bevir (editor) |title= Encyclopedia of Political Theory |publisher= ''SAGE Publications'' |quote= (see pages 452–453)... |year= 2010 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=wVIoCtB3m74C&pg=PA452&lpg=PA452&dq=%28%22equal+opportunity%22+OR+%22equality+of+opportunity%22%29+encyclopedia#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate= 2011-09-12 |isbn= 9781412958653 }}</ref> in Western nations during the last several centuries and is intertwined with social [[Social mobility|mobility]], most often with [[upward mobility]] and with [[rags to riches]] stories: {{quote|The coming President of France is the grandson of a shoemaker. The actual President is a peasant's son. His predecessor again began life in a humble way in the shipping business. There is surely equality of opportunity under the new order in the old nation.<ref name=twsH45>{{cite news |author= from The Montreal Gazette |title= Equal Opportunity |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |quote= The coming President of France is the grandson of a shoemaker. ... |date= January 20, 1906 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60F13FD3B5A12738DDDA90A94D9405B868CF1D3 |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref>}}
== Theory == === Outline of the concept === [[File:FactoryProcessing.png|thumb|In a factory setting, equality of opportunity is often seen as a procedural fairness along the lines of "if you assemble twice as many lamps, you'll be paid double" and in this sense the concept is in contrast to the concept of [[equality of outcome]], which might require that all workers be paid similarly regardless of how many lamps they made]] According to the ''[[Stanford Encyclopedia of Philosophy]]'', the concept assumes that society is stratified with a diverse range of roles, some of which are more desirable than others.<ref name=twsH11/> The benefit of equality of opportunity is to bring fairness to the selection process for coveted roles in [[corporations]], [[Voluntary association|associations]], [[nonprofit organizations|nonprofits]], [[universities]] and elsewhere.<ref name=twsL11>{{citation |author= Boyd Childress |title= Equal Opportunity |publisher= ''Encyclopedia of Business'' |date= September 12, 2011 |url= http://www.enotes.com/biz-encyclopedia/equal-opportunity |accessdate= 2011-09-12 }}</ref> According to one view, there is no "formal linking" between equality of opportunity and political structure, in the sense that there can be equality of opportunity in [[democracy|democracies]], [[autocracy|autocracies]] and in [[communism|communist nations]],<ref name=twsH11/> although it is primarily associated with a [[competitive market]] economy<ref name=twsH11/> and embedded within the legal frameworks of democratic societies.<ref name=twsL26>{{citation |author= John Michael Jenkins, J. J. J. Pigram (editors) |title= Encyclopedia of leisure and outdoor recreation |publisher= ''Routledge'' |quote= (see page 141) |year= 2005 |isbn= 0-203-67317-4 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=aNM4HnqDbAgC&pg=PA141&lpg=PA141&dq=%28%22equal+opportunity%22+OR+%22equality+of+opportunity%22%29+encyclopedia#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate= 2011-09-12 }}</ref> People with different political perspectives see equality of opportunity differently: [[Liberalism|liberals]] disagree about which conditions are needed to ensure it and many "old-style" conservatives see inequality and hierarchy in general as beneficial out of a respect for tradition.<ref name=twsL12/> It can apply to a specific hiring decision, or to all hiring decisions by a specific company, or rules governing hiring decisions for an entire nation. The scope of equal opportunity has expanded to cover more than issues regarding the rights of minority groups, but covers practices regarding "recruitment, hiring, training, layoffs, discharge, recall, promotions, responsibility, wages, sick leave, vacation, overtime, insurance, retirement, pensions, and various other benefits".<ref name=twsL11/>
The concept has been applied to numerous aspects of public life, including accessibility of polling stations,<ref name=twsH15>{{cite news |author= staff writers |title= Equality of opportunity committee |publisher= ''BBC'' |date= September 21, 2010 |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/wales/newsid_9019000/9019507.stm |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> care provided to [[HIV]] patients,<ref name=twsH17>{{cite news |author= staff writers |title= The Royal College of Nursing has called for an increase in the number of specialist nurses working with HIV patients. |publisher= ''BBC News'' |date= November 30, 2009 |url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/democracylive/hi/wales/newsid_8386000/8386264.stm |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> whether men and women have equal opportunities to travel on a spaceship,<ref name=twsH24>{{cite news |author1=Takao Ikeuchi |author2=Kaori Saito |title= Space mom wants equal opportunity for all |publisher= ''Japan Times'' |date= April 17, 2010 |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn20100417f3.html |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> [[bilingual education]],<ref name=twsH31>{{cite news |author= Robert Garcia |title= Bilingual Education Means Equal Opportunity (letter to the editor) |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= August 18, 1989 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1989/08/18/opinion/l-bilingual-education-means-equal-opportunity-513289.html |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> skin color of models in [[Brazil]],<ref name=twsH43>{{cite news |title= Brazil fashion week goes equal opportunity |publisher= ''The Daily Telegraph'' |date= June 20, 2009 |url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/lifestyle/news/brazil-fashion-week-goes-equal-opportunity/story-e6frf00r-1225737622432 |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> television time for political candidates,<ref name=twsL24>{{cite news |author= Howard Klieman |title= Equal Time Rule: U.S. Broadcasting Regulatory Rule |publisher= ''Museum of Broadcast Communications'' |date= September 12, 2011 |url= http://www.museum.tv/eotvsection.php?entrycode=equaltimeru |accessdate= 2011-09-12 }}</ref> army promotions,<ref name=twsH54>{{cite news |title= Army Promotion Process Is Held Unconstitutional by U.S. Judge |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= March 5, 2002 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/2002/03/05/us/army-promotion-process-is-held-unconstitutional-by-us-judge.html |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> admittance to universities<ref name=twsH55>{{cite news |title= Illiterate Americans (opinion) |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= September 14, 1993 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1993/09/14/opinion/illiterate-americans.html |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> and [[ethnicity in the United States]].<ref name=twsH62>{{cite news |author= Celia W. Dugger |title= U.S. Study Says Asian-Americans Face Widespread Discrimination |work= The New York Times |date= February 29, 1992 |url= https://www.nytimes.com/1992/02/29/us/us-study-says-asian-americans-face-widespread-discrimination.html |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> The term is interrelated with and often contrasted with other conceptions of equality such as [[equality of outcome]] and [[equality of autonomy]]. Equal opportunity emphasizes the personal ambition and talent and abilities of the individual, rather than his or her qualities based on membership in a group, such as a social class or race or extended family.<ref name=twsL13 /> Further, it is seen as unfair if external factors that are viewed as being beyond the control of a person significantly influence what happens to him or her.<ref name=twsL13 /> Equal opportunity then emphasizes a fair process whereas in contrast [[equality of outcome]] emphasizes a fair outcome.<ref name=twsL13 /> In sociological analysis, equal opportunity is seen as a factor correlating positively with [[social mobility]], in the sense that it can benefit society overall by maximizing well-being.<ref name=twsL13 />
=== Different types === There are different concepts lumped under equality of opportunity.<ref name=twsL18>{{citation |author = Laura, Laubeová |title = Encyclopedia of The World’s Minorities |publisher = ''Fitzroy Dearborn Publishers'' |quote = This complex and contested concept... |year = 2000 |url = http://instituty.fsv.cuni.cz/~laubeova/anglicky/research/encyclopedia/equal.htm |accessdate = 2011-09-12 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120113053952/http://instituty.fsv.cuni.cz/~laubeova/anglicky/research/encyclopedia/equal.htm |archivedate = January 13, 2012 |df = mdy-all }}</ref><ref name=twsL21/><ref>Barbara Bagihole, Equal Opportunities and Social Policy: Issues of gender, race and disability, (pp. 37–39, 183–84)London: Longman, 1997</ref><ref name=twsL21xx>{{citation |author= Mark Bevir (editor) |title= Encyclopedia of Political Theory |publisher= ''SAGE Publications'' |year= 2010 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=wVIoCtB3m74C&pg=PA452&lpg=PA452&dq=%28%22equal+opportunity%22+OR+%22equality+of+opportunity%22%29+encyclopedia#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate= 2011-09-12 |isbn= 9781412958653 }}</ref>
[[#Formal equality of opportunity|Formal equality of opportunity]] is a lack of (unfair) direct discrimination. It requires that deliberate discrimination be relevant and meritocratic. For instance, job interviews should only discriminate against applicants for job incompetence. Universities should not accept a less-capable applicant instead of a more-capable applicant who can't pay tuition.
[[#Substantive equality of opportunity|Substantive equality of opportunity]] is absence of indirect discrimination. It requires that society be fair and meritocratic. For instance, a person should not be more likely to die at work because they were born in a country with corrupt labor law enforcement. No one should have to drop out of school because their family needs of a full-time carer or wage earner.
Formal equality of opportunity does not imply substantive equality of opportunity. Firing any employee who gets pregnant is formally equal, but substantively it hurts women more.
Substantive inequality is often more difficult to address. A political party that formally allows anyone to join, but meets in a non-wheelchair-accessible building far from public transit, substantively discriminates against both young and old members as they are less likely to be able-bodied car-owners. However, if the party raises membership dues in order to afford a better building, it discourages poor members instead. Grade-cutoff university admission is formally fair, but if in practice it overwhelmingly picks women and graduates of expensive user-fee schools, it is substantively unfair to men and the poor. The unfairness has already taken place and the university can choose to try to counterbalance it, but it likely can not single-handedly make pre-university opportunities equal. [[Social mobility]] and the [[Great Gatsby curve]] are often used as an indicator of substantive equality of opportunity.<ref name="wordpress.com">https://milescorak.files.wordpress.com/2013/07/income-inequality-equality-of-opportunity-and-intergenerational-mobility.pdf</ref>
Both equality concepts say that it is unfair and inefficient if extraneous factors rule people's lives. Both accept as fair inequality based on relevant, meritocratic factors. They differ in the scope of the methods used to promote them.
==== Formal equality of opportunity ==== [[File:Diagram of equal opportunity formal model.png|thumb|325px| Formal equality of opportunity ]] Formal equality of opportunity<ref name=twsL18/> is sometimes referred to as the nondiscrimination principle<ref name=twsH74/> or described as the absence of direct discrimination,<ref name=twsL18/> or described in the narrow sense as equality of access.<ref name=twsL18/><ref>Cashmore, Ellis, Dictionary of Race and Ethnic Relations, London: Routledge, 1996</ref> It is characterized by: # Open call. Positions bringing superior advantages should be open to all applicants<ref name=twsL21/> and job openings should be publicized in advance giving applicants a "reasonable opportunity" to apply. Further, all applications should be accepted.<ref name=twsH11/> # Fair judging. Applications should be judged on their merits,<ref name=twsH11/> with procedures designed to identify those best-qualified.<ref name=twsL21/> The evaluation of the applicant should be in accord with the duties of the position and for the job opening of choir director, for example, the evaluation may judge applicants based on musical knowledge rather than some arbitrary criterion such as hair color.<ref name=twsH11/> # An application is chosen. The applicant judged as "most qualified" is offered the position while others are not. There is agreement that the result of the process is again unequal, in the sense that one person has the position while another does not, but that this outcome is deemed fair on procedural grounds.
The formal approach is seen as a somewhat basic "no frills" or "narrow"<ref name=twsL13/> approach to equality of opportunity, a minimal standard of sorts, limited to the [[public sphere]] as opposed to private areas such as the [[family]], [[marriage]], or [[religion]].<ref name=twsL13/> What is considered "fair" and "unfair" is spelled out in advance.<ref name=twsL17>{{cite news |author= Research Machines |title= equal-opportunity policy |publisher= ''Farlex'' |year= 2009 |url= http://encyclopedia.farlex.com/equal-opportunity+policy |accessdate= 2011-09-12 }}</ref> An expression of this version appeared in ''The New York Times'': "There should be an equal opportunity for all. Each and every person should have as great or as small an opportunity as the next one. There should not be the unfair, unequal, superior opportunity of one individual over another."<ref name=twsH33>{{cite news |author= Leonard K. Hirshberg |title= What "Equal Opportunity to All" Really Means |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= December 30, 1917 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F10710F6355E11738DDDA90B94DA415B878DF1D3 |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref>
[[File:Osaka07 D3M Ulrike Urbansky.jpg|thumb|The formal conception focuses on procedural fairness during the competition: are the hurdles the same height? (photo: athletes [[Ulrike Urbansky]] and [[Michelle Carey]] in Osaka)]] This sense was also expressed by [[economist]]s [[Milton Friedman|Milton]] and [[Rose Friedman]] in their 1980 book ''[[Free to Choose]]''.<ref name=twsH72/> The Friedmans explained that equality of opportunity was "not to be interpreted literally" since some children are born blind while others are born sighted, but that "its real meaning is ... a career open to the talents".<ref name=twsH72/> This means that there should be "no arbitrary obstacles" blocking a person from realizing their ambitions: "Not birth, nationality, color, religion, sex, nor any other irrelevant characteristic should determine the opportunities that are open to a person – only his abilities".<ref name=twsH72>{{citation |author1=Milton Friedman |author2=Rose D. Friedman |title= Free to choose: a personal statement |publisher= ''Harcourt'' |year= 1980 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=F5z1B5SwGUEC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22milton+friedman%22+%22free+to+choose%22#v=onepage&q=equality%20of%20opportunity&f=false |accessdate= 2011-09-08 |isbn=0547539754 }}</ref>
A somewhat different view was expressed by [[John Roemer]], who used the term ''nondiscrimination principle'' to mean that "all individuals who possess the attributes relevant for the performance of the duties of the position in question be included in the pool of eligible candidates, and that an individual's possible occupancy of the position be judged only with respect to those relevant attributes".<ref name=twsH74>{{citation |author= John E. Roemer |title= Equality of Opportunity (book title) |publisher= ''Harvard College'' |quote= (see pages 1, 2, |year= 1998 |isbn= 0-674-25991-2 |url= https://books.google.com/?id=2LfA_KjvOAsC&printsec=frontcover&dq=%22equality+of+opportunity%22#v=onepage&q&f=false |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> [[Matt Cavanagh]] argued that race and sex should not matter when getting a job, but that the sense of equality of opportunity should not extend much further than preventing straightforward discrimination.<ref name=twsH77a/>
It is a relatively straightforward task for legislators to ban blatant efforts to favor one group over another and encourage equality of opportunity as a result. [[Japan]] banned gender-specific job descriptions in advertising as well as [[sexual discrimination]] in employment as well as other practices deemed unfair,<ref name=twsH34>{{cite news |author= Akemi Nakamura |title= New equal opportunity law called a start |publisher= ''Japan Times'' |date= March 31, 1999 |url= http://search.japantimes.co.jp/cgi-bin/nn19990331a4.html |accessdate= 2011-09-08 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20121015023242/http://www.japantimes.co.jp/text/nn19990331a4.html |archivedate= October 15, 2012 }}</ref> although a subsequent report suggested that the law was having minimal effect in securing Japanese women high positions in management.<ref name=twsH42>{{cite news |author= Martin Fackler |title= Career Women In Japan Find A Blocked Path, Despite Equal Opportunity Law |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |date= August 6, 2007 |url= https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html?res=9906E3DC1430F935A3575BC0A9619C8B63&pagewanted=all |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref>{{update inline|reason=this is nearly ten years old, has the situation changed?|date=May 2017}} In the [[United States]], the [[Equal Employment Opportunity Commission]] sued a private [[test preparation]] firm, [[Kaplan, Inc.|Kaplan]], for unfairly using credit histories to discriminate against [[African Americans]] in terms of hiring decisions.<ref name=twsH44/> According to one analysis, it is possible to imagine a democracy which meets the formal criteria (1 through 3), but which still favors wealthy candidates who are selected in free and fair elections.<ref>Christiano, Thomas, 1996, The Rule of the Many: Fundamental Issues in Democratic Theory, Boulder: Westview Press</ref>
==== Substantive equality of opportunity ==== [[File:Diagram of equal opportunity substantive model.jpg|thumb|325px| Substantive equality of opportunity ]] [[File:The Great Gatsby Curve.png|thumb|crop top=10px|The [[Great Gatsby Curve]] shows that countries with more equality of wealth also have more social mobility, which indicates that equality of wealth and equality of opportunity go together:<ref name="wordpress.com"/> <blockquote>If higher inequality makes intergenerational mobility more difficult, it is likely because opportunities for economic advancement are more unequally distributed among children.<ref>[http://ftp.iza.org/dp7155.pdf Inequality of Opportunity, Income Inequality and Economic Mobility: Some International Comparisons], Paolo Brunori, University of Bari, Francisco H. G. Ferreira, World Bank and IZA, Vito Peragine, University of Bari, Discussion Paper No. 7155, January 2013.</ref></blockquote>]] Substantive equality of opportunity, sometimes called fair equality of opportunity,<ref name=twsL21/> is a somewhat broader<ref name=twsL13/> and more expansive concept than the more limiting formal equality of opportunity and it deals with what is sometimes described as indirect discrimination.<ref name=twsL18/> It goes farther and is more controversial<ref name=twsL13/> than the formal variant; and has been thought to be much harder to achieve, with greater disagreement about how to achieve greater equality;<ref name=twsL13/> and has been described as "unstable",<ref name=twsL21/> particularly if the society in question is unequal to begin with in terms of great disparity of wealth.<ref name=twsH19>{{cite news |author= Daron Acemoglu |title= How does inequality matter? (letter to the editor) |publisher= ''The Economist'' |quote= ...equality of opportunity may be harder to achieve in an unequal society... |date= January 23, 2011 |url= http://www.economist.com/economics/by-invitation/guest-contributions/economic_power_begets_political_power |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> It has been identified as more of a left-leaning political position,<ref name=twsL27>{{cite news |title= Socialism And Social Democracy |publisher= ''Encyclopedia69.com'' |year= 2011 |url= http://www.encyclopedia69.com/eng/d/socialism-and-social-democracy/socialism-and-social-democracy.htm |accessdate= 2011-09-12 }}</ref> but this is not a hard-and-fast rule. The substantive model is advocated by people who see limitations in the formal model: {{quote|Therein lies the problem with the idea of equal opportunity for all. Some people are simply better placed to take advantage of opportunity.|Deborah Orr in ''[[The Guardian]]'', 2009<ref name=twsH23>{{cite news |author= Deborah Orr |title= The problem with equal opportunity for all: Some people are better placed to take advantage of equal opportunity in our schools |publisher= ''The Guardian'' |quote= Therein lies the problem with the idea of equal opportunity for all. Some people are simply better placed to take advantage of opportunity... |date= November 5, 2009 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2009/nov/05/equal-opportunity-education |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref>}} {{quote|There is little income mobility – the notion of America as a land of opportunity is a myth.|Joseph E. Stiglitz, 2012<ref>Stiglitz, Joseph E. (June 4, 2012). The Price of Inequality: How Today's Divided Society Endangers Our Future (p. 25). Norton. Kindle Edition.</ref>}}
In the substantive approach, the starting point before the race begins is unfair since people have had differing experiences before even approaching the competition. The substantive approach examines the applicants themselves before applying for a position and judges whether they have equal abilities or talents; and if not, then it suggests that authorities (usually the government) take steps to make applicants more equal before they get to the point where they compete for a position and fixing the before-the-starting-point issues has sometimes been described as working towards "fair access to qualifications".<ref name=twsL21/> It seeks to remedy inequalities perhaps because of an "unfair disadvantage" based sometimes on "prejudice in the past".<ref name=twsL23/>
According to John Hills, children of wealthy and well-connected parents usually have a decisive advantage over other types of children and he notes that "advantage and disadvantage reinforce themselves over the life cycle, and often on to the next generation" so that successful parents pass along their wealth and education to succeeding generations, making it difficult for others to climb up a social ladder.<ref name=twsH14>{{cite news |author= John Hills |title= Equality of opportunity remains a distant ideal |publisher= ''The Guardian'' |date= January 27, 2010 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/society/joepublic/2010/jan/27/social-groups-equality-gap |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> However, so-called positive action efforts to bring an underprivileged person up to speed before a competition begins are limited to the period of time before the evaluation begins. At that point, the "final selection for posts must be made according to the principle the best person for the job", that is, a less qualified applicant should not be chosen over a more qualified applicant.<ref name=twsL18/> There are also nuanced views too: one position suggested that the unequal results following a competition were unjust if caused by bad luck, but just if chosen by the individual and that weighing matters such as personal responsibility was important. This variant of the substantive model has sometimes been called [[luck egalitarianism]].<ref name=twsL21/> Regardless of the nuances, the overall idea is still to give children from less fortunate backgrounds more of a chance,<ref name=twsH14/> or to achieve at the beginning what some theorists call equality of condition.<ref name=twsL18/> Writer Ha-Joon Chang expressed this view: {{quote|We can accept the outcome of a competitive process as fair only when the participants have equality in basic capabilities; the fact that no one is allowed to have a head start does not make the race fair if some contestants have only one leg.<ref name=twsH18>{{cite news |author= Ha-Joon Chang |title= We lost sight of fairness in the false promise of wealth: Acceptance of inequality rests on assumptions that 'free markets' make us all richer in the end. Growth figures tell it differently |work= The Guardian |date= August 30, 2010 |url= https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2010/aug/30/fairness-inequality-free-market-growth |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref>}}
[[File:Daiane Conterato2 crop.jpg|thumb|Issues about equal opportunity have been raised about the skin color of runway models at the [[São Paulo Fashion Week]] and in 2009 quotas requiring that at least 10 per cent of models be "black or indigenous" were imposed as a substantive way to counteract a "bias towards white models", according to one account<ref name=twsH43/>]] In a sense, substantive equality of opportunity moves the "starting point" further back in time. Sometimes it entails the use of [[affirmative action]] policies to help all contenders become equal before they get to the starting point, perhaps with greater training, or sometimes redistributing resources via [[restitution]] or [[taxation]] to make the contenders more equal. It holds that all who have a "genuine opportunity to become qualified" be given a chance to do so and it is sometimes based on a recognition that unfairness exists, hindering [[social mobility]], combined with a sense that the unfairness should not exist or should be lessened in some manner.<ref name=twsH13>{{cite news |author= Paul Krugman |title= Economics and Morality |publisher= ''The New York Times'' |quote= ...Access to good schools, good health care, and job opportunities depends on lot on choosing the right parents. |date= January 10, 2011 |url= https://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/01/10/economics-and-morality/ |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> One example postulated was that a warrior society could provide special nutritional supplements to poor children, offer scholarships to military academies and dispatch "warrior skills coaches" to every village as a way to make opportunity substantively more fair.<ref name=twsH11/> The idea is to give every ambitious and talented youth a chance to compete for prize positions regardless of their circumstances of birth.<ref name=twsH11/>
The substantive approach tends to have a broader definition of extraneous circumstances which should be kept out of a hiring decision. One editorial writer suggested that among the many types of extraneous circumstances which should be kept out of hiring decisions was personal beauty, sometimes termed "[[lookism]]": {{quote|Lookism judges individuals by their physical allure rather than abilities or merit. This naturally works to the advantage of people perceived to rank higher in the looks department. They get preferential treatment at the cost of others. Which fair, democratic system can justify this? If anything, lookism is as insidious as any other form of bias based on caste, creed, gender and race that society buys into. It goes against the principle of equality of opportunity.<ref name=tws2X32>{{cite news |title= For Equality of Opportunity |work= Times of India |date= September 8, 2011 |url= http://articles.timesofindia.indiatimes.com/2011-09-08/edit-page/30123525_1_discrimination-lookism-beauty |accessdate= 2012-07-24 }}</ref>|source=}}
The substantive position was advocated by [[Bhikhu Parekh]] in 2000 in ''Rethinking Multiculturalism'', in which he wrote that "all citizens should enjoy equal opportunities to acquire the capacities and skills needed to function in society and to pursue their self-chosen goals equally effectively" and that "equalising measures are justified on grounds of justice as well as social integration and harmony".<ref name=twsL18/><ref>Parekh, Bhikhu, Rethinking Multiculturalism. Cultural Diversity and Political Theory, pp. 210–11, 240, London: Macmillan Press, 2000</ref> Parekh argued that equal opportunities included so-called cultural rights which are "ensured by the politics of recognition".<ref name=twsL18/>
[[Affirmative action]] programs usually fall under the substantive category.<ref name=twsL13/> The idea is to help disadvantaged groups get back to a normal starting position after a long period of [[discrimination]]. The programs involve government action, sometimes with resources being transferred from an advantaged group to a disadvantaged one and these programs have been justified on the grounds that imposing [[:wikt:Quota|quotas]] counterbalances the past discrimination<ref name=twsH11/> as well as being a "compelling state interest" in diversity in society.<ref name=twsL13/> For example, there was a case in [[São Paulo]] in [[Brazil]] of a quota imposed on the [[São Paulo Fashion Week]] to require that "at least 10 percent of the models to be black or indigenous" as a coercive measure to counteract a "longstanding bias towards white models".<ref>{{cite news |title= Brazil fashion week goes equal opportunity |publisher= ''The Daily Telegraph'' |quote=... the Sao Paulo Fashion Week ... has imposed quotas... |date= June 20, 2009 |url= http://www.dailytelegraph.com.au/lifestyle/news/brazil-fashion-week-goes-equal-opportunity/story-e6frf00r-1225737622432 |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> It does not have to be accomplished via government action: for example, in the 1980s in the United States, President [[Ronald Reagan]] dismantled parts of affirmative action, but one report in the ''[[Chicago Tribune]]'' suggested that companies remained committed to the principle of equal opportunity regardless of government requirements.<ref name=twsH64>{{cite news |author= Carol Kleiman |title= Equal Opportunity: It's Good Business |publisher= ''Chicago Tribune'' |date= January 19, 1986 |url= http://articles.chicagotribune.com/1986-01-19/news/8601050619_1_affirmative-action-equal-opportunity-human-resource-directors |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref> In another instance, upper-middle-class students taking the [[Scholastic Aptitude Test]] in the United States performed better since they had had more "economic and educational resources to prepare for these test than others".<ref name=twsL13/> The test itself was seen as fair in a formal sense, but the overall result was seen as nevertheless unfair. In [[India]], the [[Indian Institutes of Technology]] found that to achieve substantive equality of opportunity the school had to reserve 22.5 percent of seats for applicants from "historically disadvantaged schedule castes and tribes".<ref name=twsL13/><ref name=twsL14>{{cite news |author = Kanta Murali |title = The IIT Story: Issues and Concerns |publisher = ''Frontline'' |quote = Frontline – Volume 20 – Issue 03 |date = February 1–14, 2003 |url = http://www.flonnet.com/fl2003/stories/20030214007506500.htm |accessdate = 2011-09-12 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20060326171945/http://www.flonnet.com/fl2003/stories/20030214007506500.htm |archivedate = March 26, 2006 |df = mdy-all }}</ref> Elite universities in [[France]] began a special "entrance program" to help applicants from "impoverished suburbs".<ref name=twsL13/>
==== Equality of fair opportunity ==== Philosopher [[John Rawls]] offered this variant of substantive equality of opportunity and explained that it happens when individuals with the same "native talent and the same ambition" have the same prospects of success in competitions.<ref name=twsH11/><ref name=twsH77e>{{cite news |author= John Rawls |title= A Theory of Justice |publisher= ''Harvard College'' |year= 1971 |url= https://books.google.com/books?id=tUEO9SuNG1oC&pg=PA83&dq=%22equality+of+opportunity%22&hl=en&ei=QBxqTqTfLeLv0gG27byuCQ&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=6&ved=0CEQQ6AEwBTge#v=onepage&q=%22equality%20of%20opportunity%22&f=false |accessdate= 2011-09-08 }}</ref><ref>Rawls, John, 1999, A Theory of Justice, revised edition, Cambridge: Harvard University Press</ref><ref>Rawls, John, 2001, Justice as Fairness: A Restatement, ed. by Erin Kelly, Cambridge, Harvard University Press.</ref> [[Gordon Marshall (sociologist)|Gordon Marshall]] offers a similar view with the words "positions are to be open to all under conditions in which persons of similar abilities have equal access to office".<ref name=twsL12/> An example was given that if two persons X and Y have identical talent, but X is from a poor family while Y is from a rich one, then equality of fair opportunity is in effect when both X and Y have the same chance of winning the job.<ref name=twsH11/> It suggests the ideal society is "classless" without a social hierarchy being passed from generation to generation, although parents can still pass along advantages to their children by [[genetics]] and [[socialization]] skills.<ref name=twsH11/> One view suggests that this approach might advocate "invasive interference in family life".<ref name=twsH11/> Marshall posed this question: {{quote|Does it demand that, however unequal their abilities, people should be equally empowered to achieve their goals?
